author: Claudia Assis
title: Driverless ‘crash’ trucks ready to keep road crews safe
text:
The first self-driving vehicles rolling routinely down America’s highways are not likely to be glamorous, high-end sports cars but a couple of lowly road maintenance trucks.
At least that’s how specialty-vehicle maker Royal Truck and Equipment in Coopersburg, Pa., sees things shaping up. The company said two of its so-called crash trucks, autonomously capable of following a lead car, will be on Florida roads later this year as part of a pilot program with the state’s Department of Transportation.
The trucks, with heavy-duty crash bars on the back and strobe lights up on top, are designed to provide a safety barrier between roadside construction crews and traffic whizzing dangerously close past them.
The technology used on the driverless trucks is similar to unmanned vehicle technology used by the U.S. military, said Samantha Schwartz, marketing and business development manager at Royal Truck and Equipment.
See also: Truck of future weds hybrid and solar technologies
Kratos Defense & Security Solutions Inc.’s KTOS, +7.71% Micro Systems Inc. powers the driverless truck’s technology, she said.
Several technology and car-making heavyweights are working or are reportedly working on driverless vehicles, including Apple Inc. AAPL, +2.94% and Tesla Motors Inc. TSLA, +8.07% Most experts believe, however, that true driverless cars are at least a couple of decades away despite the advances in technology and in driver-assistance features.
See also: Elon Musk: Tesla ‘almost ready’ to go driverless
After the end of the Florida pilot program, Royal will gather data and approach transportation departments in other states to find more work for its autonomous “crash” trucks. Such a truck, depending on its age and accessories, can cost anywhere from $60,000 to $100,000, a price range Schwartz said Royal roughly is trying to match with its autonomous vehicles.
“Crash” trucks protect road workers, but nothing protects the drivers of such trucks. Royal is “taking the person out of the truck meant to be hit,” Schwartz said.
